entries.name: Song of Songs (which is Solomon’s)
entries.blurb: The superlative ‘Song of Songs’ signals a collection of love poetry framed by Solomon’s name—either authorship, dedication, or Solomonic idiom. The book sanctifies marital desire within wisdom theology.

entries.name: The Beloved (Shulammite woman)
entries.blurb: Primary voice of the Song—dark yet lovely, vineyard worker turned garden of delight. She initiates pursuit (1:2–4), seeks at night (3:1–4), and claims mutual belonging (2:16; 6:3; 7:10). Background & Solomon: The text names Solomon (1:1; 3:7–11; 8:11–12) and portrays the bridegroom with royal imagery; some read the woman as **Solomon’s beloved** (Shulammite ≈ ‘Shunammite’), others see her as independent of the king, even contrasting her personal vineyard with Solomon’s commercial vineyard (8:11–12). Either way, her agency and fidelity stand central—love is covenantal, voluntary, and resilient.

entries.name: The Lover / Bridegroom
entries.blurb: Speaks with shepherd and kingly tones—leaping over mountains, crafting palanquin, crowning day of wedding. Whether identified with Solomon or read as archetypal bridegroom, he models delighted, attentive love.

entries.name: Solomon (son of David)
entries.blurb: Royal figure anchoring the Song’s frame—owner of vineyards, bearer of the wedding crown, patron of wisdom and song (1 Kgs 4:32). He can be read as the bridegroom or as symbolic foil whose grandeur is relativized by the couple’s mutual love.

entries.name: Daughters of Jerusalem (chorus)
entries.blurb: Choral companions who hear, question, and witness—liturgical audience framing love’s pedagogy. They receive the refrain ‘Do not awaken love until it pleases.’

entries.name: Brothers of the Beloved
entries.blurb: Guardians of her honor who made her keep the vineyards; later negotiate protection for a younger sister—family structures that both constrain and care.

entries.name: Watchmen of the city
entries.blurb: Public order figures: once helpful in her search; later violent guardians who beat and strip her—ambivalence of societal gatekeepers over intimate love.

entries.name: Mother’s house & maternal figures
entries.blurb: Site of nurture and intimacy; the beloved longs to bring him to her mother’s house—love is embedded in family memory and blessing.

entries.name: Companions/friends of the bridegroom
entries.blurb: Listeners near the couple’s garden; wedding-feast echoes; community delights in private joy without intrusion.

entries.name: Garden locked, a spring sealed
entries.blurb: Chastity and exclusivity: the bride as enclosed garden; love’s pleasures within covenant walls. Edenic echoes—pomegranates, spices, flowing waters.

entries.name: Vineyard imagery (own vineyard vs Solomon’s)
entries.blurb: Her ‘own vineyard’ (self/body/agency) contrasts with Solomon’s commercial vineyard with keepers—love resists commodification while inviting mutual enjoyment.

entries.name: Animals of desire and danger
entries.blurb: Gazelle and stag (agility/desire), foxes (small threats to vineyards), doves (beauty/faithfulness). Creatures voice love’s energy and vulnerabilities.

entries.name: Body metaphors of beauty
entries.blurb: Eyes as doves, hair like goats, neck as tower, teeth like shorn ewes; for him: head like gold, eyes like doves, legs like alabaster—metaphors dignify embodiment without pornographic gaze.

entries.name: Season of singing (springtime)
entries.blurb: Winter past, flowers appear, voice of the turtledove—creation’s renewal mirrors awakened love.

entries.name: Fragrance, oils, spices
entries.blurb: Nard, myrrh, frankincense, saffron, cinnamon, aloes—olfactory worship of love; sensory theology of delight.

entries.name: Architecture & towers (Heshbon, Damascus)
entries.blurb: Neck like the tower of David; nose like the tower of Lebanon—beauty pictured with civic strength; love builds, it does not merely adorn.

entries.name: City by night (search scenes)
entries.blurb: Nocturnal quests dramatize desire and vulnerability; longing refuses apathy, risks misunderstanding to find the beloved.

entries.name: Wedding day & palanquin
entries.blurb: Solomon’s litter with sixty warriors; mother crowns him on the day of gladness—public celebration of private covenant.

entries.name: Place-names & landscapes (En-gedi, Sharon, Tirzah, Jerusalem, Lebanon, Hermon, Amana, Senir)
entries.blurb: Geography becomes metaphor—strength, fragrance, fertility, majesty; love roams Israel’s map as temple-garden renewed.

entries.name: Covenantal love: strong as death
entries.blurb: Set me as a seal upon your heart and arm—the seal marks ownership and permanence; love’s flame is ‘a flame of YH’ (shalhevetyah). Many waters cannot quench love.

entries.name: Mutuality and consent
entries.blurb: ‘Draw me after you’; ‘I am my beloved’s and he is mine’—mutual belonging and initiative contrast with exploitative eros; desire is dialogical and dignifying.

entries.name: Do not awaken love until it pleases (refrain)
entries.blurb: Chastity refrain anchors timing—desire awaits proper season; love’s discipline enhances joy.

entries.name: Eden restored in the temple-garden
entries.blurb: Garden, rivers, fruitful trees, and unashamed delight—wisdom’s end is not mere restraint but redeemed eros woven into creation’s praise.

entries.name: Canonical/typological horizons
entries.blurb: Israel as YHWH’s bride; Christ and the Church as later reading—yet the literal marital sense remains the text’s primary register; typology arises from covenant patterns, not allegory alone.

entries.name: ‘Your love is better than wine’
entries.blurb: Opening prayer of desire—love surpasses luxury; the king brings her into his chambers, yet agency remains with the woman’s voice.

entries.name: ‘Catch for us the foxes’
entries.blurb: Small threats spoil vineyards—early vigilance protects tender love; community (‘for us’) guards covenant joy.

entries.name: ‘My beloved is mine, and I am his’
entries.blurb: Triple confession of mutual possession charts growth: from possession to priority (‘I am my beloved’s’).

entries.name: ‘Who is this coming up from the wilderness’
entries.blurb: Exodus echoes—love emerges from wilderness into wedding. Salvation history becomes marriage imagery.

entries.name: ‘Turn, turn, O Shulammite’
entries.blurb: Public gaze on private beauty—dance imagery raises questions of objectification vs celebration; the text leans toward covenant festivity guarded by consent.
